I.  THE ONGOING PROGRAM 
 
1.  ADB’s Trade Finance Program (TFP) fills market gaps by providing guarantees and loans 
to partner banks in support of trade. Since 2009, TFP has supported more than 12,000 small and 
medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) across developing Asia and the Pacific – through over 16,500 
transactions valued at over $30 billion – in sectors ranging from commodities and capital goods, 
to medical supplies and consumer goods. In 2017, the TFP supported $4.5 billion in trade through 
approximately  3,500  transactions.  The  TFP  also  encourages  commercial  sustainability  by 
promoting environmental and social safeguards standards, ensuring integrity and transparency, 
as  well  as  helping  accelerate  progress  in gender  equality.  TFP  is  also  supporting  digital 
transformation as it pertains to trade finance. 
  
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  Trade finance is explicitly recognized in the Addis Ababa Action Agenda on Financing for 
Development as an important means of implementing the Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs).1 However, an ADB survey published in September 2017 estimated a global trade finance 
gap of $1.5 trillion, 40% of which is in Asia and the Pacific, with 74% of rejected trade finance 
transactions coming from SMEs. Private sector funding and support is critical to address the large 
market gaps for short-term trade finance that exists across Asia and the Pacific.2 Thus, to address 
such market deficiencies, ADB, in accordance with Strategy 2030, will expand the use and reach 
of its various financial sector programs such as trade finance and supply chain finance.3  
 
3.  The proposed $3.0 million technical assistance (TA)4 will help TFP to continue to address 
market gaps for trade finance and therefore support more trade by building on the initiatives 
started under previous TFP TAs and introduce new initiatives.5 The TA will provide TFP with funds 
to engage consultants over the next three years to assist in various capacity building initiatives 
for  enhanced  safeguards,  integrity  due  diligence  related  to  combatting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, gender/disability policies, and digitization of trade 
finance in TFP partner banks. The TA will also fund related knowledge-sharing and partnership 
activities. These will include seminars and regional trainings for developing member country 
(DMC) banks, their SME clients, and related government agencies.   
 
4.  Safeguards Initiative. The TA will create awareness of and help address social and 
environmental issues such as child/forced labor, climate change and sustainability through the 
banking sector, which is expected to also impact banks’ clients, including SMEs. The effects of 
these various social and environmental safeguards issues are seen globally, but much more so 
in developing countries where it inflicts the most economic and social costs. Many DMCs where 
TFP operates are considered climate-vulnerable because of the importance of climate-sensitive 
sectors in their economies (i.e. agriculture) and because of limited resource capacity to respond

to climate change. Many of these adverse effects contribute to poverty, particularly impacting 
women and children.  
 
5.  Deepening financial institutions’ awareness and understanding of environmental and 
social safeguards through formulating safeguards guidelines and conducting safeguards due 
diligence as well as trainings and workshops is expected to result in enhanced safeguards 
capacity within TFP and its partner banks and may also result in safeguards improvements 
beyond the scope of banks’ trade finance business such as in terms of accessing direct debt or 
equity finance opportunities from ADB.  Enhanced safeguards capacity is also expected to 
translate into increased support for trade, for example, of agricultural commodities into DMCs that 
may be affected by climate change-related events (i.e., severe flooding), enabling DMCs to 
become more resilient to direct and indirect impacts of climate change. 
 
6.  Anticorruption and Integrity Measures. Following the global financial crisis, compliance 
and regulatory requirements have increased significantly for banks, including in trade finance. 
Consequently, ‘de-risking’ of correspondent banking relationships is affecting trade in DMCs. TFP 
partner  banks,  including  those  in  the  Pacific,  are  witnessing  a  decline  in  correspondent 
relationships to clear transactions and/or issue trade finance instruments. Trade for these banks 
is dampened and therefore overall economic growth and job creation will slow.  In an extreme 
scenario, de-risking could isolate countries from the global financial and trading system.   Part of 
the  problem  cited  by  financial  institutions  and  DMCs  alike  is  the  different  definitions  and 
treatments by financial regulators on how to comply with anti-financial crimes and integrity due 
diligence and regulations.  Correspondent banks note that varying compliance requirements can 
add  costs  and  risks  to  on-boarding  and  maintaining  correspondent  banking  relationships, 
especially in DMCs. The TA will support strengthening of practices related to combating corruption, 
money laundering, and the financing of terrorism measures.  It will also improve monitoring of 
such issues by conducting integrity due diligence reviews on all TFP partner banks and financial 
institutions. 
 
7.  The TA will also complement the work of the Financial Stability Board (FSB) and the 
Financial Action Task Force (FATF) and align with the efforts of numerous industry bodies in this 
area by further analyzing the development of a scorecard to assess the implementation and 
effectiveness of global regulations with respect to anti-money laundering and combating terrorism 
financing regulations, and then support follow-on initiatives. It is anticipated that this initiative will 
encourage greater harmonization between regulatory jurisdictions, clarify, simplify and reduce 
costs of compliance and therefore mitigate the problems associated with de-risking. 
 
8.  Gender Equity and Inclusive Initiatives. Gender equity initiatives will continue to be 
implemented and the program will set a minimum threshold of 30% for the percentage of female 
participants in any TFP training. In 2016, the TFP launched a gender initiative aimed at attracting, 
retaining, and promoting women in banking and trade. To date, the human resource policies of 
20 TFP partner banks have been assessed for possible human resource policy enhancements. 
Consultants will be engaged under the TA to implement recommendations and future phases of 
this initiative following results of the TFP gender study published in May 2018.6 This may also 
include social protection elements such as establishing disability-friendly facilities in the workplace 
and ensuring gender-inclusiveness in the banks’ human resource policies. 
 
9.  Digitization of Trade. While there is intense discussion around and promotion of the 
digitization of trade and fintech’s ability to close market gaps and deliver on the ‘inclusive economy’ 
                                                
6 ADB. 2018. Boosting Gender Equality Through ADB Trade Finance Partnerships. Manila.

3 
agenda, basic rules, standards, protocols and best practices need to be introduced to support 
growth and innovation. The TA will support an initiative (“Digital Standards in Trade (DST)” or the 
“Universal Trade Network” (UTN) or whatever name and structure may be determined most 
appropriate by the industry) with the private and public sectors on a cost-sharing basis to create 
digital rules, standards, protocols and practices required to digitize trade, drive inter-operability 
and underpin progress in fintech to reduce financing gaps among SMEs and DMCs. DST/UTN 
(or by some other name) will coordinate with all stakeholders to create and drive global adoption 
of the standards and practices that will serve as basic infrastructure for the digitization of trade.  
 
10.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030. Through TFP’s gender equity and safeguards 
initiatives, the TA supports ADB’s Strategy 2030 operational priorities B, C and D with regard to 
accelerating gender equality, tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, 
and enhancing environmental sustainability, as well as building more livable cities by making them 
more resilient and inclusive. The TA likewise incorporates guiding principles for ADB’s operations 
on promoting innovative technology and digital transformation by conducting pilot testing related 
to digitization of trade processes and documents. Moreover, the proposed capacity building and 
knowledge-sharing and collaboration activities under the TA demonstrates ADB’s role as a 
knowledge institution and knowledge provider and promotes ADB’s Strategy 2030 key operational 
priorities F and G related to strengthening governance and institutional capacity and fostering 
regional cooperation and integration through trade.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.   The TA is estimated to cost $3,000,000, of which (i) $750,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s TASF- Others, (ii) $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis by Financial Sector 
Development Partnership Special Funds (FSDPSF)8 and (iii) 1,500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by Urban Climate Change Resilience Trust Fund (UCCRTF)9 under the Urban Financing 
Partnership Facility (UFPF) and administered by ADB. The funds will cover remuneration, travel, 
and  per  diem  for  international  consultants  and  national  consultants,  conference  related 
expenditures, and miscellaneous expenses. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA. PSOD will select, supervise and evaluate the consultants. The

14.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. Consultants will procure works and goods (as applicable). Individual 
consultants will be recruited to provide international and national consulting inputs. Resource 
persons will also be engaged for trainings and seminars.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of TA not exceeding the equivalent of 
$750,000 to be financed on a grant basis by FSDPDF, (ii) ADB administering a portion of TA not 
exceeding the equivalent of $1,500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by UCCRTF under the 
UFPF; and (iii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant 
basis, for Capacity Building for Enhanced Safeguards, Anti-Corruption and Integrity Measures, 
Gender Equity Policies and Digitization of Trade Finance Program Banks, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.
